channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Facebook Deletes Post on Tibetan Monk’s Self-Immolation
item.description: Tsering Woeser, a writer in Sichuan Province and prominent critic of Chinese policies toward Tibetans, said Facebook deleted her post on the self-immolation of the 37-year-old monk Kalsang Yeshi, without explanation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Before the Chinese Year of the Sheep, a Bulge in Births
item.description: Parts of China have seen full maternity wards, as parents try to take advantage of the auspicious Year of the Horse and avoid giving birth in the less fortuitous Year of the Sheep.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: A hospital in Beijing. Mothers-to-be are trying to avoid giving birth in the less fortuitous Year of the Sheep.

item.title: Kilinochchi Journal: Postwar Sri Lanka’s Awkward Peace
item.description: The Sinhalese of the victorious south happily tour the war-ravaged north, where some of the defeated northern people receive them warily.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Ethnic Tamils gathered on Oct. 13 to welcome the Queen of Jaffna as it arrived at its northern terminal in Sri Lanka after being out of service for 24 years.

item.title: In Shadow of New Search, a Long Aviation Mystery Remains Unsolved
item.description: The Australian and Malaysian governments still have ships scouring the Indian Ocean for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared on March 8.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Battle to Defang ISIS, U.S. Targets Its Psychology
item.description: Officials acknowledge they have barely made a dent in the larger, longer-term campaign to kill the ideology that animates the terrorist movement.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Gen. Michael K. Nagata wants fresh ideas to defeat ISIS.

item.title: Indonesian Agency Says Missing AirAsia Jet Probably Sank
item.description: The head of the agency searching for Flight 8501 said that he believed the aircraft was “at the bottom of the sea” and warned that the country lacked adequate equipment for an underwater search.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Loved ones awaited word on Sunday about Air Asia Flight 8501, which had 162 people on board.

item.title: Hamas Turns Back 37 Gaza War Orphans From a Bridge-Building Trip to Israel
item.description: Israeli and Palestinian officials had organized the visit for 37 children from Gaza as a way to promote peace and reconciliation, but the Hamas authorities turned them back at a border crossing.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:description: Activists waiting at the Erez border crossing Sunday for youths from Gaza, who had set out for a rare visit to Israel before Hamas turned them back.

item.title: Radio Station Backed by U.S. Is Raided in Azerbaijan
item.description: A dozen employees of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, including an anchor and the cleaning woman, were arrested and detained for up to 12 hours over the weekend, as prosecutors intensified a crackdown on journalists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: ‘Monster Strike’ Gives Former Social Media Giant Mixi a Second Act
item.description: Mixi was a once-dominant social network that Facebook had driven to the edge of collapse — and then it created the mobile game Monster Strike.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Kenji Kasahara, founder of Mixi. Once Japan’s dominant social network, the company was driven to near-collapse by Facebook.

item.title: Libyan Militias Set Fire to Storage Tanks in Renewed Push for Oil, Foreign Minister Says
item.description: About 850,000 barrels of oil had been lost because of a fire in five storage tanks, an oil corporation official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Around an Invisible Leader, Taliban Power Shifts
item.description: The reclusiveness of Mullah Muhammad Omar raises questions about the group’s leadership and its influence in the jihadist world next to the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Where Afghan War Was Transferred Long Ago
item.description: The official conclusion of the international combat mission in Afghanistan arrived Sunday, but for the Afghans fighting in this remote border district, the symbolic end to America’s 13-year war brought little change.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Gen. John F. Campbell, the top American commander in Afghanistan, rolled up his forces’ flag.

item.title: Bomb in India Kills Woman in Busy Center of Bangalore
item.description: An explosive device that was placed between two flower pots outside a restaurant also wounded a man in an attack the police commissioner said had been “aimed at causing panic and fear.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 2014 Proves a Grim Year in Malaysian Aviation
item.description: Should no survivors be found aboard the missing AirAsia flight, Malaysian carriers, or their subsidiaries, will have been involved in the world’s three deadliest aviation disasters this year.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A relative of passengers of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, the plane that disappeared in March, watched a news broadcast about the missing AirAsia Flight 8501 in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India and the Right to Suicide
item.description: By allowing its citizens the ultimate freedom - the choice to kill oneself - the country becomes a truer democracy.
item.dc:creator: By JERRY PINTO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Caving In to China's Power
item.description: Many of the same leaders who complain about Chinese censorship quietly accept the censorship themselves.
item.dc:creator: By MARK KITTO

item.title: A Former Ground Zero Goes to Court Against the World’s Nuclear Arsenals
item.description: The Marshall Islands, the Pacific atolls where Americans once conducted nuclear tests, want to spur global disarmament in a case before the world’s top court.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: A nuclear test in the Marshall Islands, one of 67 conducted by the United States in the area.

item.title: Critic's Notebook: In Haiti, Battling Disease With Open-Air Clinics
item.description: Two new clinics in Haiti for treating cholera and tuberculosis could be models for other struggling countries that lack resources for high-end Western-style hospitals.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: The Facts on AirAsia Flight 8501
item.description: AirAsia Flight 8501 disappeared in the same part of the world as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 but differs in important ways.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: AirAsia Airbus A320 passenger jets on the tarmac in Sepang, Malaysia, in November. Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501, an Airbus A320, disappeared from radar screens early Sunday.

item.title: Hundreds Stranded as Ferry Catches Fire Off the Greek Coast
item.description: Rescuers battled rough seas to reach the stricken ferry that caught fire off the northwestern coast of Greece on its way to Italy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The ferry Norman Atlantic after it caught fire in the Adriatic Sea on Sunday.
